headline: Garbine Muguruza Defeats Serena Williams to Win the French Open
summary: Garbine Muguruza defeats Serena Williams to win the women's  French Open title

headline: Ali’s Family Plans Parade, Memorial Service in Louisville
summary: The beloved boxing champion, who was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease three decades ago, died of septic shock, a family spokesman said.

headline: Former Prime Minister of Spain Meets With Jailed Venezuelan Opposition Leader
summary: Spain’s former prime minister met with jailed Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo López on Saturday, the first meeting of its kind in the more than two years since his imprisonment for inciting violence during antigovernment protests.

headline: In the Ring: Speed, Stamina and Psychological Warfare
summary: Asked to describe the man he trained for over 20 years, Angelo Dundee shook his head in wonder and replied, “Being with Muhammad was like riding a comet,” and a comet he was.

headline: The Spiffy Hawaiian Shirt Is Back for Summer
summary: Aloha shirts are no longer the punch line to a bad joke. The breezy top is returning to its refined roots and making a comeback as an alternative to bright polos and T-shirts.

headline: Clinton Calls Trump ‘Dangerous,’ ‘Bigoted’ in His Comments on Judge
summary: Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton on Saturday issued her most stinging rebuke yet of presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump’s criticism of a federal judge, calling his remarks “dangerous” and “bigoted.”

headline: Canada’s Energy Sector to Aid Economic Recovery From Wildfires
summary: About half of the expected damage to Canada’s economy from the wildfires in Alberta was caused by lost crude production, which should bounce back as energy producers resume operations, Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz said.

headline: Massachusetts Looks to Expand Antidiscrimination Law to Gender Identity
summary: Massachusetts may soon have a new law broadly allowing people to use restrooms and locker rooms that match their gender identity, marking a likely victory for transgender advocates.

headline: Marlins Scoreboard Becomes Surprising Outlet to Break News of Ali’s Death
summary: Before most of the world knew Muhammad Ali had died, an unexpected scene unfolded at Marlins Park on Friday night: A photo of him appeared on the scoreboard with his name and “1942-2016,” indicating his passing.

headline: Louisville Remembers Its Favorite Son
summary: Muhammad Ali’s hometown of Louisville, Ky., mourned the passing of its favorite son, with makeshift memorials, long lines at the museum dedicated to him and with tales of their encounters with the Champ.

headline: Serena Williams Defeated by Muguruza for French Open Title
summary: Garbiñe Muguruza, a 22-year-old from Spain, achieved a rare feat at the French Open: She overpowered Serena Williams in a Grand Slam final.

headline: Syrian Troops Advance on Islamic State Stronghold
summary: Syrian troops reached the edge of the northern province of Raqqa, home to the de facto capital of Islamic State’s self-styled caliphate, in a push that leaves the extremists fighting fierce battles on four fronts in Syria and Iraq.

headline: Kaczynski Objects to Foreign Criticism of Polish Politics
summary: The leader of Poland’s governing party said he would resist pressure from foreign governments to end the country’s constitutional crisis on the opposition’s terms.

headline: Photos: Muhammad Ali—a Champ Outside the Ring
summary: Boxing legend Muhammad Ali was as much a showman outside the ring as he was inside, and he was feted far and wide for his achievements, as pictures from the time show.

headline: Wal-Mart CEO Touts Tech
summary: At its annual shareholder meeting, Wal-Mart showed off its use of drones in warehouses and voted in founder Sam Walton’s 34-year-old grandson as a board member.

headline: Pope Allows Easier Dismissal of Bishops Who Cover Up Sex Abuse
summary: Pope Francis made it easier to remove Catholic bishops who mishandle cases of clerical sex abuse, in his latest effort to fill a widely criticized gap in the church’s approach to the problem.

headline: Muhammad Ali Shook Up the World
summary: In the chaos following his career-making triumph over Sonny Liston in Miami in 1964, Muhammad Ali found his way to a microphone and camera in the crowded boxing ring and bellowed five words that announced his arrival: “I shook up the world!” That he did.

headline: Dozens Injured by Lightning Strikes at German Festival
summary: Scores of people have been injured by lightning strikes at a rock festival in western Germany, police said.

headline: Four Dead From Flooding Around Paris
summary: French authorities raised the death toll from severe flooding around the capital to four, as the Seine river’s water levels fell after hitting a high mark overnight.

headline: Valeant Looks to Show Steps Toward Normalcy
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals will try to show it is putting months of turmoil over drug-price increases and business practices behind it when it reports earnings Tuesday.

headline: What Is Parkinson’s Disease?
summary: Muhammad Ali lived with the degenerative disease for three decades.

headline: How to Get the Right Financial Adviser
summary: Financial advisers like to say the good ones are worth their weight in gold.

headline: Colombia Beats U.S. at Copa America
summary: The U.S. men’s national soccer team opened the tournament with a 2-0 loss.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Calls for China to Respect Maritime-Claim Ruling Grow
summary: Western officials ramped up calls for China to respect an impending ruling from a Hague tribunal on Beijing’s maritime claim to the South China Sea.

headline: Boxer Ali, ‘the Greatest,’ Dies at 74
summary: Muhammad Ali, one of the most influential athletes in American history and a three-time heavyweight champion, died on Friday at 74. The legendary boxer leaves a legacy unmatched in sports—a charismatic champion of free speech and civil change.
